[000109] In certain embodiments, the packaging assemblies of the invention are useful for storing, distributing, treating, mixing, and dispensing implantable material, said implantable material including, but not limited to, viable tissue, nonviable tissue, dry tissue, wet tissue, soft tissue, bone, tissue derived material, synthetic biomaterial, engineered biomaterial, natural polymers, human cellular material, animal cellular material, stem cellular material, differentiated cellular material and mixtures thereof. In
some embodiments, the implantable material is a synthetic material such as tricalcium phosphate, a natural biomaterial such as a collagen-based scaffold, tissue that may be decellularized and freeze-dried or mixtures thereof.
Example 1: Cryopreservation of viable bone chips in a pouch

[000110] Human corticocancellous bone containing viable cells was ground into bone chips with certain particle sizes. The bone chips were then washed and processed to remove blood, immunogenic cells, mesenchymal cells, and maintained viable bone lineage committed cells. The viable bone chips were packaged in a pouch made from fluorinated ethylene propylene (FEP) (see e.g., FIG. 2). The port (9) consisted of FEP tubing fitted with a threaded kynar female luer (9) connected to a swabable connector ( 10). The length of the pouch was pre-determined based on the volume of the bone chips to be loaded in the pouch in order to provide sufficient empty space in the pouch to accommodate any cryopreservation media, washing solution, or biological fluids. The port was sealed by the swabable valve (4) in the female luer lock connector (10a). Viable bone chips were loaded into the pouch from the opening at end (5) of the pouch (see, e.g., FIGS. 2A AND 2B), maintained at 2-8 °C, and sealed using a heat sealer at the opening at end (5). At this point, pre-cooled cryopreservation solution in a syringe was injected into the pouch using the connector 10. Visible air bubbles were removed through the same connector (10).

Optionally, a cap (11) may be applied to the male luer lock adapter (12). The sealed package was placed into a secondary pouch made from FEP which was sealed again. The entire package was frozen at a controlled freezing rate of about -1°C per minutes to about - 70°C or lower, placed in a box, and stored in vapor phase liquid nitrogen for an extended period of time. It is understood that the vapor phase liquid nitrogen has a temperature range between about -135 °C and -190 °C.

[000111] For thawing, the box was removed from the storage tank and the secondary package was peeled off. The sealed package was placed in a sterile container with a sterile isotonic solution (35-39°C, such as 0.9% sterile saline), to thaw viable bone chips quickly. A sterile empty syringe was then connected to the connector (10) and the preservation media was removed. The tissue/cellular material was further washed twice by injecting and removing a Lactaid Ringer's solution containing 5% Dextrose through connector (10). The sealed end of the pouch (5) was cut open and over 90% of the viable bone chips were retrieved from the pouch and placed in a container.
Example 2: Cryopreservation of a viable amniotic membrane tissue in a pouch

[000112] Human amniotic membrane was isolated from fresh placenta tissue, washed, processed, placed on a sterile nitrocellulose membrane with the epithelium side facing up, and cut to sizes. One sheet of the viable human amniotic membrane (2 x 4 cm) including nitrocellulose membrane with epithelium layer facing up was added into the pouch through the opening at end (5) of the pouch (see, e.g., FIG. 3A). The length of the pouch was pre-determined based on the size of the sheet to be loaded in the pouch to provide sufficient empty space in the pouch to accommodate any cryopreservation media, washing solution, or biological fluids. The port was then sealed using the swabable valve (4) in the female luer lock connector (2). The viable amniotic membrane was kept at 2-8 °C and sealed using a heat sealer at the opening end (5) of the pouch. A pre-cooled

cryopreservation solution in a syringe was then injected slowly into the pouch using the connector (2). The fluid had direct contact with the epithelium side of membrane while the nitrocellulose membrane was in direct contact with the pouch. Visible air bubbles were removed through the same connector (2). Optionally, a cap (11) may be applied to the connector (2). The sealed package was placed into a secondary pouch made from FEP which was sealed again. The entire package was frozen at a controlled freezing rate of about -1°C per minute to about -70°C or lower, placed in a box, and stored in vapor phase liquid nitrogen for an extended period of time.

[000113] For thawing the tissue, the box was removed from the storage tank and the secondary package was peeled off. The sealed package was placed in a sterile container with a sterile isotonic solutions (35-39°C, such as 0.9% sterile saline) to thaw the viable amniotic membrane quickly. A sterile empty syringe was then connected to the connector (2) and the preservation media was quickly removed. The tissue/cellular material was further washed twice by injecting and removing the Lactaid Ringer's solution containing 5% Dextrose through connector (2). The sealed end of the pouch (5) was cut open and the viable amniotic membrane was retrieved from the pouch.
Example 3: Storage and delivery of freeze dried corticocancellous and demineralized bone matrix.
[000114] Human corticocancellous bone was ground into bone chips with certain particle sizes. The bone chips were then cleaned, disinfected using AlloWash ® Technology and freeze-dried.

[000115] Demineralized fiber bone was prepared by cutting cortical bone to produce cut fiber bone having an average length from about 1 mm to about 100 mm. The cut fiber bone was then cleaned and disinfected, and the bone materials were demineralized using PAD® technology to 1-4% residual calcium. The bone fibers were finally washed in ultrapure water, stored frozen at -70 °C in a sterile container, and freeze-dried.

[000116] Human corticocancellous and demineralized fiber bone were mixed at a 1: 1 volume ratio and packaged in a pouch made from fluorinated ethylene propylene (FEP) (see e.g., FIG. 1). The length of the pouch was pre-determined based on the volume of the bone chips to be loaded in the pouch to provide sufficient empty space in the pouch to accommodate any biological fluids. The port was sealed using the swabable valve (4) in the female luer lock connector (2). The bone matrices were loaded into the pouch from the opening at end (5) of the pouch (see, e.g., FIGS. 1A and IB) and sealed using a heat sealer at the opening at end (5). Air was then removed through the connector (2) to create a vacuum environment in the pouch. The sealed package was placed into a secondary pouch made from FEP, which was sealed again. The entire package was stored at room temperature (e.g., from about 15-25 °C). The package may be optionally sterilized using gamma irradiation.
Example 4: Storage and delivery of freeze dried corticocancellous and deminerlaized bone matrix.
[000117] Human corticocancellous bone was ground into 1-8 mm bone chips. The bone chips were then cleaned, freeze-dried, and sterilized using AlloWash ® Technology.

[000118] Human cortical bone particles with particle size range from 250 to 1000 micron were cleaned, disinfected using AlloWash® process, and dermineralized using PAD® technology to about 1-4% residual calcium. The demineralized bone particles were finally washed in ultrapure water, stored frozen at -70 degree C in a sterile container, and freeze- dried.
[000119] Human corticocancellous and demineralized bone particles were mixed at a 1:1 volume ratio and packaged in a pouch made from fluorinated ethylene propylene (FEP) (see e.g., FIGS. 1A and IB). The length of the pouch was pre-determined based on the volume of the bone chips to be loaded in the pouch to provide sufficient empty space in the pouch to accommodate any biological fluids. The port was sealed using the swabable valve (4) in the female luer lock connector (2). The bone matrices were loaded into the pouch from the opening at end (5) of the pouch (see, e.g., FIGS. 1A and IB) and sealed using a heat sealer at this same opening. The sealed package was placed into a secondary pouch made from FEP, which was sealed again. The entire package was stored at room temperature for an extended period of time. The package may be optionally sterilized using gamma irradiation.

[000120] Before implantation, the box was removed and the secondary package was peeled off. The sealed package was placed on a sterile field. A syringe containing 0.9% saline was connected to the connector (2), and the saline was injected into the pouch to pre-wet the tissue for about two minutes or more. The saline solution was then removed. A sterile empty syringe was connected to the connector (2) and pulled to remove residual fluids and air to create a vacuum environment in the pouch. A syringe containing autologous bone marrow aspirate (BMA) was connected to the connector (2), and the BMA was injected into the pouch. Due to the vacuum environment in the pouch, the bone matrix may efficiently absorb the bone marrow aspirate and allow an efficient cell attachment on the bone matrix. The BMA was allowed to clot for about 10-20 minutes. The sealed end of the pouch (5) was cut open and the bone matrix containing BMA was able to slide out of the pouch into a container.
Example 5: Package, storage, and delivery of injectable particulate dermal matrix

[000121] Decellularized human dermis was pulverized to form a fine particulate and then freeze-dried. While decellularized human dermis was used in this particular example, other types of tissue also can be used, including, but not limited to, fascia, tendon, cartilage, muscle, placenta tissue and mixtures thereof. The freeze-dried dermis particulates were loaded into the flexible pouch to fill approximately half the volume of the pouch. The pouch was sealed below the particulate with a first seal locking plastic clip (75) to contain the particulate. FIG. 17 illustrates one embodiment that is useful for this example. The open end of the pouch was filled with phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) and
the open end of the pouch was sealed with a second seal. The pouch may be stored at room temperature or at refrigerated temperature (e.g., from about 0 °C to about 25 °C).

[000122] Prior to being used in the operating room, the first seal locking clip was removed and the dried dermis particulate was reconstituted in the PBS by massaging the pouch. A 60cc syringe was attached to the luer-style port on the pouch. The slurry was then drawn out of the pouch using the attached 60cc syringe. A 20G blunt stainless steel needle was attached to the syringe and the slurry was pushed through the needle.
Example 6: Package, storage and delivery of flowable dermal matrices

[000123] Acellular human dermis was pulverized to form a fine particulate and then freeze-dried. While acellular human dermis was used in this particular example, other types of tissue also can be used, including, but not limited to, fascia, tendon, cartilage, muscle, placenta tissue and mixtures thereof. The freeze-dried dermis particulate was loaded into the flexible outer pouch (68) that contains two inner pouches (69). Each inner pouch was sealed with isotonic saline. FIG. 15 illustrates one embodiment that is useful for this example. The outer pouch was sealed close to the end of the pouch opening (71). The pouch may be stored at room temperature or at refrigerated temperature (e.g., from about 0 °C to about 25 °C).

[000124] Prior to being used in the operating room, the outer pouch was squeezed sufficiently to rupture the wall of the inner pouches thus releasing the saline solution into the freeze-dried dermis particulate. The dermis particulate was then mixed with the saline solution by massaging the outer pouch. A 10 cm long silicone tubing was attached to the luer-style port on the pouch (70). The slurry was then squeezed out of the pouch through the tubing and applied to the field of interest.
Example 7: Package, storage and delivery of shaped demineralized bone sponge

[000125] Demineralized bone fibers were compressed in a pre-shaped mold to form a sponge. While demineralized bone fibers were used in this particular example, other types of tissue also can be used, including, but not limited to, viable or non viable bone particles , bone sheets, soft tissue, cartilage, and mixtures thereof. FIG. 2 illustrates one embodiment that is useful for this example. The size of the pouch was pre-determined based on the size of the sponge to be loaded in the pouch in order to provide sufficient empty space in the pouch to accommodate any fluids. The port was sealed by the
swabable valve (4) in the female luer lock connector (10a). The shaped demineralized bone fibers were loaded into the pouch from the opening at end (5) of the pouch (see, e.g., FIGS. 2A AND 2B) and sealed using a heat sealer at the opening at end (5). The pouch may be stored at room temperature or at refrigerated temperature (e.g., from about 0 °C to about 25 °C).

[000126] Prior to being used in the operating room, a syringe containing autologous bone marrow aspirate (BMA) or blood was attached to the connector (2), and the BMA or blood was injected into the pouch. The bone matrix may efficiently absorb the bone marrow aspirate and allow an efficient cell attachment on the bone matrix. The BMA was allowed to clot for about 10-20 minutes. The sealed end of the pouch (5) was cut open and the bone matrix containing BMA was able to slide out of the pouch into a container.

[000127] It is to be understood that the scope of the present invention is not to be limited to the specific embodiments described above. The invention may be practiced other than as particularly described and still be within the scope of the accompanying claims.

[000128] It is to be understood that the scope of the present invention is not to be limited to the specific embodiments described above. The invention may be practiced other than as particularly described and still be within the scope of the accompanying claims.

claim.claim-text: 1. A packaging assembly useful for storing tissue and/or cellular material comprising: a pouch made of a sealable, flexible polymeric material and open at one end; and a needle-free swabable connector attached to the pouch at the other end and acting as a port to allow for the introduction or discharge of biological solutions, rinsing solutions, or preservation solutions into the packaging assembly.
2. The packaging assembly of claim 1 wherein the pouch is sealed on both sides of the connector at an angle of about 5 to about 60 degrees with respect to the end of the pouch.
3. The packaging assembly of claim 1 wherein the open end of the pouch is sealable.
4. The packaging assembly of claim 1 wherein the wall thickness of the flexible polymeric material is between about 0.003 inches and about 0.006 inches.

5. The packaging assembly of claim 1 wherein polymeric material is selected from the group consisting of fluorinated ethylene propylene (FEP), polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE), perfluozlkoxy polymer resin (PFA), Ethylene tetrafluoroethylene (ETFE),
Polyetheretherketone (PEEK), Polyvinylchloride (PVC), Polyethersulfone (PES),

Polyethylene (PE, of various types), Polyurethane (PU), Polyetherimide, PEI, Cyclic Olefin Copolymer (COC), Polycarbonate (PC), Polysulfone (PS), Polypropylene (PP), BPA free polyester, ethylene-vinyl acetate copolymer, ethylene-vinyl alcohol copolymer, polyesters, polyamides, polypropylenes, polyurethanes, and polyvinylidenefluoride.
6. The packaging assembly of claim 1 wherein the connector further comprises a luer lock adapter.

7. The packaging assembly of claim 1 wherein the tissue and/or cellular material is selected from the group consisting of viable tissue, nonviable tissue, dry tissue, wet tissue, soft tissue, bone, cartilage, human cellular material, animal cellular material, stem cellular material, differentiated cellular material and mixtures thereof.

8. The packaging assembly of claim 1 wherein the biological solution is selected from the group consisting of normal saline, lactated ringers, lactated ringers containing dextrose, culture media, plasma, blood, bone marrow aspirate, cells, platelet rich plasma, platelet poor plasma, growth factors, cytokines, collagen, elastin, laminin, basement membrane proteins, amniotic fluid, synovial fluid and mixtures thereof.

9. The packaging assembly of claim 1 wherein the preservation solution is selected from the group consisting of saline, glycerol, hyaluronic acids, alginate, chitosan, lactated ringers, lactated ringers containing dextrose, serum, serum albumin, dimethyl sulfoxide, glucose, trehalose, vitamins, culture media, plasma, platelet rich plasma, platelet poor plasma and cryopreservation media and mixtures thereof.
10. The packaging assembly of claim 1 further comprising at least one additional needle-free swabable connector located on the pouch.
11. The packaging assembly of claim 1 wherein the open end of the pouch is connected to a rigid tube.
12. The packaging assembly of claim 11 wherein the rigid tube has a beveled edge at its point of connection with the flexible pouch.

13. The packaging assembly of claim 11 wherein the rigid tube is adapted for engagement with a plunger, said plunger adapted for discharging tissue and/or cellular material from the packaging assembly.

14. The packaging assembly of claim 12 wherein the rigid tube is adapted for engagement with a needle comprising one or more side channels, said needle adapted for adding cellular material and/or biological solutions to the packaging assembly.

15. A kit including the packaging assembly of claim 11, said kit further comprising a plunger adapted for discharging tissue and/or cellular material from the packaging assembly; and a needle comprising one or more side channels, said needle adapted for adding cellular material and/or biological solutions to the packaging assembly.
16. The packaging assembly of claim 1 wherein the pouch is sealed in a substantially circular pattern that is open to the connector.
17. The packaging assembly of claim 1 wherein the pouch comprises one or more compartments.
18. An assembly useful for storing tissue and/or cellular material comprising:
a tube made of a rigid polymeric material and having a threaded, removable cap at one end; and

a needle-free swabable connector attached to the tube at the other end and acting as a port to allow for the introduction or discharge of biological solutions and preservation solutions into the assembly.
19. The assembly of claim 18 wherein the tube is adapted for engagement with a plunger, said plunger suitable for discharging tissue and/or cellular material from the assembly.
20. A method of cryopreserverving tissue and/or cellular material comprising:
(a) preparing tissue and/or cellular material for storage;

(b) loading the tissue and/or cellular material into a pouch made of a sealable, flexible polymeric material open at one end and adapted for a needle-free swabable connector that is attached to the pouch at the other end;
(c) sealing the open end of the pouch;
(d) injecting a cryopreservation fluid into the pouch through the connector;
(e) freezing the pouch until the temperature of the pouch reaches about -70 °C or lower; and
(f) storing the pouch at -70 °C or lower.
21. The method of claim 20 wherein the tissue and/or cellular material comprise bone chips.
22. The method of claim 21 wherein the bone chips comprise human corticocancellous bone chips.
23. The method of claim 20 wherein the tissue and/or cellular material comprise a tissue membrane.
24. The method of claim 21 wherein the bone chips are prepared through washing and processing to remove blood and immunogenic cells.

25. The method of claim 20 wherein, prior to the freezing step, the pouch is placed in a secondary pouch which in turn is sealed, the secondary pouch being made of a sealable, flexible polymeric material.
26. The method of claim 20 further comprising thawing the cryopreserved tissue and/or cellular material, the method comprising:
(g) placing the pouch in a sterile container with sterile isotonic solution at a temperature from about 35 °C to about 39 °C;
(h) removing the preservation solution from the pouch via the connector;
(i) washing the tissue and/or cellular material by injecting a physiological solution; and
(j) opening the sealed end of the pouch to retrieve the tissue and/or cellular material.
27. The method of claim 26 wherein over 90 % of the tissue and/or cellular material is retrieved from the pouch.
28. The method of claim 26 wherein the tissue and/or cellular material is washed with Lactated Ringer's solution.

29. A method of storing freeze dried corticocancellous and demineralized bone matrix comprising:
(a) grinding human corticocancellous bone into bone chips;
(b) cutting cortical bone to produce cut bone fibers having an average length of from about 1 mm to about 100 mm;
(c) cleaning, disinfecting and demineralizing the cut bone fibers to contain about 1-4% calcium;
(d) washing the bone fibers in water;
(e) storing the bone fibers at about -70 °C or lower in a sterile container and freeze-drying;
(f) mixing the human corticocanellous bone chips and the demineralized bone fibers at about a 1:3 to 3:1 ratio by volume;

(g) loading the mixture of human corticocanellous bone chips and demineralized bone fibers into a pouch made of a sealable, flexible polymeric material open at one end and adapted for a needle-free swabable connector that is attached to the pouch at the other end; and
(h) sealing the open end.
30. The method of claim 29 further comprising the following step (i): removing air from the pouch through the connector to create negative pressure in the pouch.
31. The method of claim 29 wherein the pouch is stored at a temperature of from about 15 °C to about 25 °C.
32. A method of storing freeze dried corticocancellous and demineralized bone matrix comprising:
(a) grinding human corticocancellous bone into bone chips;
(b) cleaning, disinfecting and demineralizing human cortical bone particles;
(c) washing the bone particles in water;
(d) storing the bone particles at about -70 °C or lower in a sterile container and freeze-drying;
(e) mixing the human corticocanellous bone chips and the demineralized cortical bone particles at about a 1:3 to about 3:1 ratio by volume;

(f) loading the mixture of human corticocanellous bone chips and demineralized bone particles into a pouch made of a sealable, flexible polymeric material open at one end
and adapted for a needle-free swabable connector that is attached to the pouch at the other end; and
(g) sealing the open end.
33. The method of claim 32 wherein bone particles have a particle size ranging from about 250 to about 1000 microns such that the particles have about 1-4% residual calcium
34. The method of claim 32 wherein the pouch is stored at a temperature of from 15- 25 °C.
35. The method of claim 32 further comprising:
(h) optionally injecting a physiological solution into the pouch using a syringe attached to the connector;

(i) optionally allowing the physiological solution to pre-wet the mixture of human corticocanellous bone chips and demineralized bone particles prior to removing the physiological solution from the pouch;
(j) evacuating residual fluids and air from the pouch to create a vacuum therein; (k) injecting autologous bone marrow aspirate into the pouch through the connector; and
(I) allowing the autologous bone marrow aspirate to clot.
36. The method of claim 35 further comprising opening the sealed end of the pouch to extract the mixture of human corticocanellous bone chips and demineralized bone particles.
37. The method of claim 35 wherein residual fluids and air are evacuated from the pouch by connecting an empty sterile syringe to the connector and pulling until a vacuum is created in the pouch.
38. A method of storing and delivering a particulate tissue comprising:
(a) pulverizing decellularized tissue to form particulates;

(b) freeze drying said pulverized tissue;
(c) loading the freeze-dried pulverized tissue into a pouch made of a sealable, flexible polymeric material open at one end and adapted for a needle-free swabable connector that is attached to the pouch at the other end, wherein about 25% to about 75% of the volume of the pouch is filled with the tissue;
(d) sealing the open end with a first seal to contain the pulverized tissue;
(e) filling the open end of the pouch with isotonic solution;
(f) sealing the open end of the pouch with a second seal; and
(h) storing the pouch at a temperature less than about 25 °C.
39. The method of claim 38 further comprising:
(i) removing the first seal from the pouch
(j) massaging the pouch to reconstitute the freeze-dried pulverized tissue in the isotonic solution to form a slurry; and
(k) evacuating the slurry from the pouch using a syringe attached to the needle- free swabable connector.
40. The method of claim 38 wherein the first seal is a clip or a clamp.
41. The method of claim 38 wherein the tissue is dermis.
42. A method of storing and delivering a particulate tissue comprising:
(a) pulverizing tissue to form particulates;
(b) freeze drying said pulverized tissue;

(c) loading the freeze-dried pulverized tissue into a pouch made of a sealable, flexible polymeric material open at one end and adapted for a luer-style port attached to the pouch at the other end, and containing one or more inner pouches made of a biocompatible material, said inner pouches being more easily ruptured than the outer pouch and containing isotonic solution;
(d) sealing the open end of the pouch; and
(e) storing the pouch at a temperature less than about 25 °C.
43. The method of claim 42 further comprising:
(f) squeezing the outer pouch sufficiently to rupture the walls of the inner pouches thus releasing isotonic solution;
(g) massaging the pouch to reconstitute the freeze-dried pulverized tissue in the isotonic solution to form a slurry; and
(k) evacuating the slurry from the pouch using tubing attached to a luer-style port on the pouch.
44. The method of claim 42 wherein the tissue is dermis.
45. A packaging assembly useful for storing implantable material comprising:

a pouch made of a sealable, flexible polymeric material and open at one end; and a needle-free swabable connector attached to the pouch at the other end and acting as a port to allow for the introduction or discharge of biological solutions and preservation solutions into the packaging assembly.
46. The packaging assembly of claim 45 wherein the pouch is sealed on both sides of the connector at an angle of about 5 to about 60 degrees with respect to the end of the pouch.
47. The packaging assembly of claim 45 wherein the open end of the pouch is sealable.
48. The packaging assembly of claim 45 wherein the wall thickness of the flexible polymeric material is between about 0.004 inches and about 0.006 inches.

49. The packaging assembly of claim 45 wherein polymeric material is selected from the group consisting of fluorinated ethylene propylene (FEP), polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE), perfluozlkoxy polymer resin (PFA), Ethylene tetrafluoroethylene (ETFE),
Polyetheretherketone (PEEK), Polyvinylchloride (PVC), Polyethersulfone (PES),

Polyethylene (PE, of various types), Polyurethane (PU), Polyetherimide, PEI, Cyclic Olefin Copolymer (COC), Polycarbonate (PC), Polysulfone (PS), Polypropylene (PP), BPA free polyester, ethylene-vinyl acetate copolymer, ethylene-vinyl alcohol copolymer, polyesters, polyamides, polypropylenes, polyurethanes, and polyvinylidenefluoride.
50. The packaging assembly of claim 45 wherein the connector further comprises a luer lock adapter.

51. The packaging assembly of claim 45 wherein the implantable material is selected from the group consisting of viable tissue, nonviable tissue, dry tissue, wet tissue, soft tissue, bone, cartilage, tissue derived material, synthetic biomaterial, engineered biomaterial, natural polymers, human cellular material, animal cellular material, stem cellular material, differentiated cellular material and mixtures thereof.

52. The packaging assembly of claim 45 wherein the biological solution is selected from the group consisting of normal saline, lactated ringers, lactated ringers containing dextrose, culture media, plasma, blood, bone marrow aspirate, cells, platelet rich plasma, platelet poor plasma, growth factors, cytokines, collagen, elastin, laminin, basement membrane proteins, amniotic fluid, synovial fluid and mixtures thereof.

53. The packaging assembly of claim 45 wherein the preservation solution is selected from the group consisting of saline, glycerol, hyaluronic acids, alginate, chitosan, lactated ringers, lactated ringers containing dextrose, serum, serum albumin, dimethyl sulfoxide, glucose, trehalose, vitamins, culture media, plasma, platelet rich plasma, platelet poor plasma and cryopreservation media and mixtures thereof.
54. The packaging assembly of claim 45 further comprising at least one additional needle-free swabable connector located on the pouch.
55. The packaging assembly of claim 45 wherein the open end of the pouch is connected to a rigid tube.
56. The packaging assembly of claim 55 wherein the rigid tube has a beveled edge at its point of connection with the flexible pouch.
57. The packaging assembly of claim 55 wherein the rigid tube is adapted for engagement with a plunger, said plunger adapted for discharging implantable material from the packaging assembly.

58. The packaging assembly of claim 56 wherein the rigid tube is adapted for engagement with a needle comprising one or more side channels, said needle adapted for adding implantable material and/or biological solutions to the packaging assembly.

59. A kit including the packaging assembly of claim 55, said kit further comprising a plunger adapted for discharging implantable material from the packaging assembly; and a needle comprising one or more side channels, said needle adapted for adding implantable material and/or biological solutions to the packaging assembly.
60. The packaging assembly of claim 45 wherein the pouch is sealed in a substantially circular pattern that is open to the connector.
61. The packaging assembly of claim 45 wherein the pouch comprises one or more compartments.
62. A packaging assembly useful for storing implantable material comprising:
(a) an outer pouch made of a sealable, flexible polymeric material open at one end and adapted for a luer-style port attached to the outer pouch at the other end; and

(b) one or more inner pouches contained within the outer pouch, the one or more inner pouches made of a biocompatible material, said one or more inner pouches being more easily ruptured than the outer pouch, wherein the one or more inner pouches contain a fluid which may be released by squeezing the outer pouch sufficiently to rupture the walls of the one or more inner pouches, and wherein the implantable material in the outer pouch can be mixed with the fluid released from the one or more inner pouches by massaging the outer pouch.
63. The packaging assembly of claim 62 wherein the fluid is a wetting agent and/or biological agent of the implantable material in the outer pouch.
64. The packaging assembly of claim 62 wherein the implantable material is a synthetic material, a natural biomaterial, tissue or mixtures thereof.
65. A kit comprising:
a pouch made of a sealable, flexible polymeric material;
tissue and/or cellular material contained within the pouch, the pouch including particulate tissue having viable cells; and

a needle-free swabable connector attached to the pouch and acting as a port , wherein the port is designed to permit the introduction and withdrawal of cryopreservation solutions, rinsing solutions, or biological solutions, and
wherein the pouch is designed to facilitate delivery of the tissue and/or cellular material.
66. The kit of claim 65 wherein the biological solution is plasma, blood, bone aspirate, platelet rich plasma, platelet poor plasma, or mixtures thereof.
